Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Short- and Standard-Length Stems in Cementless Total Hip Arthroplasty

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included age ≥20 years, no prior hip surgery, and absence of metabolic bone disease.

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either a short stem (n = 56) or a standard-length stem (n = 44)

Objective.evidence: This study assesses the effectiveness of short stems compared to standard-length stems.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of thigh pain over a 5-year follow-up.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: randomised to receive either a short stem (n = 56) or a standard-length stem (n = 44) from March 2013 to January 2014.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Thigh pain was reported in 16% (9/56) of the short-stem group and 14% (6/44) of the standard-stem group (p = 0.79).

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.
